definitions.definition: A movement in people or things with a particular way in large numbers or amounts
The movement of a real or figurative fluid.
A formalization of the idea of the motion of particles in a fluid, as a group action of the real numbers on a set.
definitions.example: The notion of flow is basic to the study of ordinary differential equations.

definitions.definition: The rising movement of the tide.
Smoothness or continuity.
definitions.example: The room was small, but it had good symmetry and flow.

definitions.definition: The amount of a fluid that moves or the rate of fluid movement.
definitions.example: Other devices measure water flow in streams fed by melted ice.

definitions.definition: A flow pipe, carrying liquid away from a boiler or other central plant (compare with return pipe which returns fluid to central plant).
A mental state characterized by concentration, focus and enjoyment of a given task.
The emission of blood during menstruation.
definitions.example: Tampons can be small or large, slender or thick. From “slender” to “super”, you can pick the size that matches your flow.

definitions.definition: The ability to skilfully rap along to a beat.
definitions.example: The production on his new mixtape is mediocre but his flow is on point.

definitions.definition: To move as a fluid from one position to another.
definitions.example: Rivers flow from springs and lakes.

definitions.definition: To proceed; to issue forth.
definitions.example: Wealth flows from industry and economy.

definitions.definition: To move or match smoothly, gracefully, or continuously.
definitions.example: The writing is grammatically correct, but it just doesn't flow.

definitions.definition: To have or be in abundance; to abound, so as to run or flow over.
To hang loosely and wave.
To rise, as the tide; opposed to ebb.
definitions.example: The tide flows twice in twenty-four hours.

definitions.definition: To arrange (text in a wordprocessor, etc.) so that it wraps neatly into a designated space; to reflow.
To cover with water or other liquid; to overflow; to inundate; to flood.
To cover with varnish.
To discharge excessive blood from the uterus.
A morass or marsh.
